I think it's quite likely he will. He doesn't need to get 50% of the vote, he merely needs to get more than the other two candidates. Trump has demonstrated again and again the resilience of the 35% of America that has an almost religious fervor to their support of him, I believe Arpaio will benefit from a similar effect. I suspect Trump will endorse him 60/40. Outliers would be if Trump or a family member is indicted or if Arpaio does something so overtly racist and offensive that it will be impossible to defend. Note that I believe he likely won't win the Senate seat. I think that if Arpaio wins the Republican nomination, it's quite likely the seat will flip Democratic.

Primary's not until Aug 28th so we've got a long time to go to see how the idea of Arpaio sits with voters and how long each of their funding lasts leading up to the primary.  Probably more likely to get a general feel for the way things are leaning through May June and see it pick up in July and early August. Polling so far suggests that McSally loses fewer votes in polls than Ward once Arpaio entered the race, which suggests as others here have pointed out that Trump & Ward appeal to the same hard line groups.  
https://ballotpedia.org/United_States_Senate_election_in_Arizona_(August_28,_2018_Republican_primary)
https://realclearpolitics.com/epolls/2018/senate/az/arizona_senate_republican_primary-6235.html Ward has been pushing away from her Bannon connection as superficial and emphasizing connections to well-established Republicans over Trump & others.  As the previous front runner before Arpaio entered (when McSally moved up) and one of three candidates in a very tight race so far, if she thought playing toward Trump and the classic Trump campaign method were a safe thing, she would include them and then remind audiences of other connections and history as well.  She probably wants to set herself apart from Arpaio but also seems to find that a more open (though not more moderate) party stance is more tenable than a MAGA/Trump-or-Bust focus.
https://www.cnn.com/2018/02/21/politics/kelli-ward-arizona-dc/index.html I suspect that many Republicans like the idea of siding with Arpaio as someone strongly in their corner, but the GOP also wants to win the AZ senate seat and they demonstrated considerable concern that his win in the primary would turn an otherwise likely GOP win into a much closer contest with Democrats over a seat that more than ever needs to stay Republican.  
https://www.azcentral.com/story/news/politics/elections/2018/01/26/resolution-nudge-joe-arpaio-out-senate-race-withdrawn-arizona-gop-activist/1068146001/ Arpaio seems to have been fairly quiet, by comparison or at least media are less willing to grant him news time as quickly or willingly).  I imagine the harder he would push for support & funding in established party areas with long-term senate seat goals, the more likely he is to get mixed signals and lukewarm support.  The more he comes out swinging verbally in public and uses reputation and public sentiment to gather strength, I think the more he stands a good chance of having it work against him over the long term, giving other GOP candidates content for criticisms against him and stiffening moderate and democratic antipathy for him in the final election should he win the primary.   I'm not sure there's much of a safe path for campaigning aggressively that will suit Arpaio's style and not also work against him.  He's maintaining a Trumpian, out-to-get-me/we-must-defend-ourselves campaign focus and doubling down on the things than made him infamous, which I would guess will remain strong but not expand his support much and may reduce his support in the end.
https://www.tahoedailytribune.com/news/local/arizona-senate-candidate-joe-arpaio-tells-nevadas-lawmakers-they-need-to-support-president-trump/

If he ends up with a formal Trump endorsement, he's actually projected to win the GOP primary. Yes, he's old, and yes, his scorched-earth politics turn off a lot of voters even from the GOP, but unless one of the other candidates drop out, it seems we have to respect the polling somewhat. My forecast takes into account that despite polling at 35% and being the frontrunner of the GOP primary with a theoretical Trump endorsement, his weakness as a candidate would still make him likely to underperform his polling numbers in my view.

US primary elections are heavily swayed by political party campaign funding and which candidate they decide to back.  The Republican and Democratic parties want to back winners and Joe Arpaio is an unlikely winner in the general election in November, if he were to win the Republican nomination on August 28.  From the list of declared candidates, Representative Martha McSally would be the best choice for Republican campaign money in that election.  Joe Arpaio is a candidate who will be easy to defeat with enough rope to hang himself and President Trump's support.  Arpaio is a fringe candidate for voters that keep the Fox News television channel on a loop in their household.  Arizona is a moderately conservative state.  Senator Flake and Senator McCain are a reflection of Arizonans' past choices and Arpaio is too far right to win a primary.  He has gained named recognition through Fox News and his policies as a former sheriff racially profiling Hispanics, dressing men in pink jumpsuits while incarcerated and making them sleep outdoors in tents.  He is 85 years old and lost his most recent election as an incumbent for the sheriff position he held for 24 years.  He may be good for a sound bite or two during the campaign and a couple of votes from dim wits on August 28.
"Movement-Base" Republicans will support and more pragmatic Republicans will have difficulty falling in line behind one strong candidate.

McSally has to be favored at this exact moment and an Arpaio candidacy would essentially cede the seat to the Democrats... but never underestimate how driven modern Republican voters are by emotion.  And Arpaio is all emotion... specifically anger.
His age is a factor, and I am fairly certain he will have some kind of political dirt thrown at him.
Old people vote in primaries, simple as that.. but that's all he has going for him.
Campaign may fizzle by them plus up against a strong candidate in Martha Mc Sally.  He'd also be aged 86 by then which is a grand old age to be taking on so much responsibility.

While Arpaio has a strong base in Maricopa County, he has a lot of baggage and very little appeal to center of right GOP. Martha McSally is a much more palatable option for the general election at a time when conservatives are seeing the 2018 election as a referendum on their 'culture war' and would rather support a viable candidate like McSally to prevent the loss of the Senate to Democrats.

I'm moving my probability from 33% to 37% because I think Ward's fundraising might be drying up.  My understanding is that McSally is a Republican establishment favorite, which is why I'm not going higher at this time.

The most likely impact of a sustained Arpaio is to split the vote with Kelli Ward (should she stay in). That will allow a more electable - in the general election that is - Republican pick up the nomination. Arpaio voters were either most likely not going to vote in a primary or to vote for Ward; he has a strong but narrow base (probably less than 1/3 of the primary base). If Ward even gets 1/5th or a bit more, that lets a third, more moderate, candidate take the nomination and, thus, increase the chances that the Republicans keep the seat. If he and Ward stay in the race, it is a net plus for the chances of the GOP to keep the seat since they split the non-moderate base.

I believe that there is enough anger in Arizona's inner-cities over "Plexiglas", that "law and order" may appear to be their only alternative.

Arizona tends towards the far right, and Arpaio typifies that stance.

Arpaio is fairly popular in his district

He has strong name recognition, much of which will be positive with the base. He's also clearly non-establishment, which has been a positive in recent Republican primaries in other high-profile races. He's also capable of turning his recent pardon into an emblem of pride, demonstrating Trump's support for him, particularly on immigration issues. (& if DREAM Act or similar legislation passes, will probably boost his chances to account for base anger). But he's also highly controversial, McSally has a compelling narrative and broad support base, and his age may lead to campaigning difficulties). Current polling has him slightly behind McSally, but within margin.

https://www.realclearpolitics.com/epolls/latest_polls/elections/
Arizona Senate - Republican Primary 	ABC 15/OH Predictive Insights 	McSally 31, Arpaio 29, Ward 25 	McSally +2

With a crowded field and the remaining string from Moore in Alabama, there will likely be less of an appetite for Arpaio style antics in such a competitive state. Still, with the current state of the party, these concerns might no win out.
Two stronger contenders in the race. Arpaio has a strong but narrow base and does not appeal to the establishment Republican party voters.

Arpaio is a controversial candidate facing two fierce primary challengers at a time when Republicans cannot afford to lose a Senate seat. This hurts his odds of running an effective primary campaign and/or receiving a much-needed endorsement from Mr. Trump. Even with an endorsement from Trump, Arpaio will struggle to win a majority of primary voters considering the dynamic between Arpaio and the two opposing candidates Kelli Ward and Martha McSally. Ward has actively voiced the anti-establishment, MAGA "red meat" rhetoric that appeals to Trump Republicans and she will surely double down on this approach during the primary while finding ways to show she is the better MAGA candidate than Arpaio. Comparing their personalities and Ward's broad legislative experience to Arpaio's narrow focus as Sheriff suggests Ward will effectively address more issues that impact everyday life while Arpaio will be less comfortable outside of issues relating to immigration and law enforcement. While Arpaio's unsympathetic and legally-challenged history as Sheriff may be a selling point for some, it will be easy fodder for negative ads. This will give Ward better chances to win over women who support Trump and voters who hold net neutral-to-positive views of immigrants. This dynamic will fracture the pro-Trump Republican base and deny Arpaio the unified base he needs to secure the nomination. While Ward lacks Arpaio's national notoriety and has not raised significant funds, she ran a competitive primary campaign against McCain in 2016 is likely to win enough would-be Arpaio voters to deny him the nomination. While Ward and Arpaio battle for the support of the hard-right and Trump voters, the other Republican candidate, Martha McSally, will have a greater degree of freedom to address broad-base issues without necessarily rebuking the Trump base. McSally has reported the most campaign funds of the three candidates, is leading in the polls (as of today) and is expected to receive full support from the RNC and Mitch McConnell. Given Trump's failed endorsements in Alabama and his constant shift away from Banon's anti-establishment rhetoric toward unity with McConnell and Paul Ryan, it's reasonable to assume Trump will be pressured to follow the party line and endorse mainstream candidates like McSally. Facing historically dim prospects for the 2018 midterms, Republicans will go all-out to keep seats in Congress and McSally is their best bet to win the general election. If Trump were to endorse Arpaio, it would hurt Republican chances and more Republican losses represent an existential threat to Trump's presidency. Trump's decision making has historically followed his own self-interests over any given person, party, or policy position. Trump will likely face impeachment with a Democratic majority in congress, so he will do what he must to prevent this from happening. Therefore, it is more likely that he will endorse McSally over Arpaio because McSally is widely seen as the best chance for Republicans to win that Senate seat.
I see him doing worse than Roy Moore, he is similarly polarizing and is in a less red state.

Joe Arpaio represents a continuation of the Trump era of election by name recognition.  The larger the rift between Democrat views and the candidate has proven to create a fervor among the right base.   The question only requires that he win the Republican nomination and does not ask about the actual election to the seat.  Republican leaders have been capitulating to the desires of the extreme right with blogs like Brietbart out of fear of creating animosity among Trump-type voters. Considering the case study of Roy Moore, Brietbart pits established Republicans against extreme right wing candidates like Roy Moore (http://www.breitbart.com/big-government/2017/12/12/establishment-republicans-cheer-roy-moores-loss-in-alabama/).   Even mainstream conservative outlet, Fox News, considered Roy Moore to be "a sticky wicket." (http://www.foxnews.com/opinion/2017/12/11/should-conservatives-vote-for-roy-moore.html) and pointed to his deep evangelical roots as justification for why his allegations should be ignored and he deserved the Republican vote.  
Joe Arpaio is a Roy Moore without allegations of sexual misconduct; rather, he holds extreme views on immigration that caused him legal trouble when he was found to be carrying out policies that he was directed to stop.  The right base will likely resonate with his views on immigration and find that he was a victim of a "politicized" legal process similarly to President Trump and the current notion that the FBI has become a political opponent.  
However, the current field is crowded with other qualified Republicans and few polls even include Arpaio.  However, when he is included in the polls, he is in second beating out other candidates that were leading just months ago (https://www.cnn.com/2017/08/22/politics/kelli-ward-arizona-senate-race/index.html, https://ballotpedia.org/United_States_Senate_election_in_Arizona_(August_28,_2018_Republican_primary)).  
Should Joe Arpaio decide to enter the race, he will have a significant chance of winning the nomination.  As of now, his chances are slim as he is not even a real contender in the race.

Joe Arpaio represents a continuation of the Trump era of election by name recognition.  The larger the rift between Democrat views and the candidate has proven to create a fervor among the right base.   The question only requires that he win the Republican nomination and does not ask about the actual election to the seat. Considering the case study of Roy Moore, Brietbart pits established Republicans against extreme right wing candidates like Roy Moore (http://www.breitbart.com/big-government/2017/12/12/establishment-republicans-cheer-roy-moores-loss-in-alabama/). Should Joe Arpaio decide to enter the race, he will have a significant chance of winning the nomination.  As of now, his chances are slim as he is not even a real contender in the race.
The support for Arpaio is shallow and he is not a viable candidate.  I am also sure his age will be an issue.
There will be a backlash against Jeff Flake, and more towards conservatism
Kelli Ward may split nationalist right votes with Arpaio. McSally hasn't officially joined the race. 25% odds for Ward as well. 50% odds for McSally.

Of Republican voters in Arizona, about 15% are over 64. This is his likeliest group of supporters but he won't get them all. He will pick up a little more support from other age groups, but is unlikely to go get significant support overall due to age/reputation issues.

To much baggage, not to dissimilar to Moore.  Trumps brand doesn't count for anything very much.  I believe the folks in Ariz will see through the neo-conservative goals and certainly Flake will not be in Arpaios' corner.

"At a recent party meeting in Phoenix, candidates down the ballot introduced themselves as Trump allies"--Trump is very popular now in Arizona.  Arpaio's politics are popular there.  He has name recognition.  He has a reputation for not changing his opinions and like his opinions or not, at least voters know where he stands.  That can't be said of many politicians.  He seems to be pragmatic and knows issues that impact people like drug addiction and family violence and loss of nuclear families impact on juvenile delinquency and future crime and gun violence as well as drug running across the borders and illegal immigration.  He has had to enforce laws written by others. He understands unintended consequences. Just as a soldier has credibility for military issues, this former sheriff has credibility many hot button issues. But the election is some time away. Arizona Republicans are conservative but not retrograde.  They tend to turn out pretty good candidates (although they will then, often but not always, vote for whatever character gets the party's nod).  They will have noticed that (a) there are several solid conservative candidates who walk erect and breath through their nostrils, and (b) Arpaio couldn't carry Maricopa County at gunpoint.  Whoever gets this nomination, it won't be him.

It's hard to believe that the same voters who elected Jeff Flake, the epitome of a principled Conservative and a fine example of behavior both personally and as Senator, would turn 180 degrees and vote for someone whose entire behavior in inappropriate in every measure.

Flake is a conservative in name only, he really conserves nothing.  The chance of Arpaio riding the wave of populism to primary victory is good, but I would question dirty tactics by liberals to vote in the primary as republicans to remove him from the general election. The will is there, but cheating may stop it.

In prior republican primary elections for US Senate in Arizona, the perceived further-right candidate has lost in the last three elections, (Will Cardon, JD Hayworth, and Kelli Ward). However, Kelli Ward and Joe Arpaio attract a similar type of republican voter, and are seen in Arizona as the vehemently pro-Trump candidates, and that may serve to split the field in McSally's favor. However, if Pres. Trump supporters are convinced that Arpaio is closer to the President (due to a coming endorsement from the President, the Presidential pardon, or any other reason) this split could be marginal and fall for Arpaio.  McSally, if any of the prior elections were to serve as a predictor would be the favorite at the outset and the split in the wing of the party gives her a further advantage.  From all the readily available information I would predict that Arpaio has a 20% chance to win the Republican Primary as it currently stands. I would double this likelihood if President Trump formally  endorses Arpaio, and most likely triple it if Kelli Ward were to drop out of the race.

Joe Arpaio and Kelli Ward are basically attracting the same type of voter, so there's a good chance they will split the vote and leave some room for McSally to actually win the primary.  The unknown is who Trump is going to support between Arpaio and Ward and how much weight that will carry this time in August.

Full disclosure:  I have been wrong a lot about elections in the last couple of years.  This has prompted unfamiliar feelings of humility, since before the last couple of years I was almost never wrong about elections.  One hopes that none of the major deities has decided to teach me a lesson by punishing everyone else in the US, and for that matter the world.
